title: Almost 800 Isis supporters escape Syrian camp after Turkish military attack
text:
Turkish troops and Turkish-backed Syrian rebels gather outside the border town of Ras al-Ain. Picture: NAZEER AL-KHATIB/AFP via Getty Images.

The relatives of Islamic State fighters have escaped a displacement camp held by Kurdish forces in northern Syria after Turkey launched a fierce military attack.

The Kurdish-led administration said 785 Isis prisoners – including the wives and children of members – managed to flee the Ain Issa camp in which they were being held after fresh shelling this morning.

It was the latest assault by Turkish-backed soldiers in the region since the country began its offensive on Wednesday.

According to the United Nations, over 130,000 people have already been displaced but despite international condemnation, Turkey looks set to continue its assault on Syria for nine more days.

On Saturday evening, Boris Johnson urged Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan to halt the attack.

Advertisement

In a phone call, the prime minister warned of his ‘grave concern’ the military action could undermine the fight against Isis and compound Syria’s humanitarian situation after nine years of war..

He called on President Erdogan to enter into a dialogue with a view to end the conflict.

Boris Johnson has called for a ceasefire (Picture: Getty Images)

A Downing Street spokesman said: ‘Mr Johnson expressed the UK’s grave concern about Turkey’s military operation in northern Syria, which he said could further worsen the humanitarian situation there and undermine the progress made against Daesh (so-called Islamic State).

‘The prime minister underlined that Turkey is an important partner for the UK and a Nato ally.

‘He recognised Turkey’s role at the forefront of the fight against (ISIS) and its generosity in supporting refugees who’ve fled the civil war in Syria.

‘But the prime minister was clear that the UK cannot support Turkey’s military action. He urged the president to end the operation and enter into dialogue, and said the UK and international partners stand ready to support negotiations towards a ceasefire.’

Turkish-backed Syrian rebels gather outside the border town of Ras al-Ain (Picture: Nazeer Al-khatib / AFP)

Flames rise from burned cars following an explosion in the central Qamishli city in northeastern Syria (Picture: AP)

People gather at the site of an explosion in the northeastern Syrian Kurdish city of Qamishli. Photo: AFP.

Syrians gather at the site of an explosion in the northeastern Kurdish city of Qamishli on October 11, 2019. Photo: AFP.

Turkish forces have argued the offensive, which was triggered after US President Donald Trump withdrew American troops from Syria, is necessary to create a safe zone along the border, where it plans to move over three million refugees.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Erdogan has moved to justify the attacks as an attempt to remove a terrorist threat against his country from the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces.

But Kurdish forces have warned of a ‘humanitarian catastrophe’ that could unfold because of the Turkish military operation.

And Mr Trump has said the US does not endorse the assault on northern Syria against Kurdish fighters who helped the US defeat Isis.

Mr Johnson’s intervention came after Germany and France announced they had suspended all exports to Turkey.

Local residents cheer and applaud as a convoy of Turkish forces trucks transporting tanks is driven to Sanliurfa province, southeastern Turkey, at the border with Syria. Photo: AP.

People hold a Turkish flag as they give their support to the Turkish military during the deployment of tanks to Syria. Photo: AP.

People hold up a Turkish flag as they show their support to the Turkish military during the deployment of Turkish tanks to Syria. Photo: AP.

On Saturday, Turkish-backed Syrian troops were reported to have taken over Ras al-Ain – a key border town in the region.

Reports estimate that as many as 40 people have been killed in the operation, including civilians, and five Isis suspects have escaped from prison in Qamishli following Turkish shelling.

Elsewhere Unicef reported that a safe water pump in Ras al-Ain for at least 400,000 poeple was left out of service after being attacked, while two schools in Tal Abiad were taken over for military use.

The aid agency has hundreds of staff providing help to refugees in displacement camps.

Advertisement

A spokesperson for Unicef said: ‘An escalation of hostilities in the area is likely to have serious consequences on the ability of humanitarian actors to provide protection and assistance to thousands of vulnerable children.

‘Unicef reiterates that the only solution to the brutal conflict in Syria is a political solution.’

The European Union’s foreign affairs committee is set to meet in Luxembourg today to decide upon a co-ordinated approach.

A woman is taken out of a building after it was hit by mortar shells fired from Syria, in the Turkish border town of Akcakale. Picture: REUTERS/Stoyan Nenov.

People gather at the site of an explosion in the northeastern Syrian Kurdish city of Qamishli. Picture: AP.

Syrians gather at the site of an explosion in the northeastern Kurdish city of Qamishli. Photo: AFP.

People walk in Akcakale, Sanliurfa province, southeastern Turkey, as in the background, Turkish forces artillery pieces fire targets towards Syria,Photo: AP.

description: Boris Johnson has urged the Turkish president to halt his military attack against Syrian Kurds.
